![](featured.jpg)

## Introduction

We will get acquainted with the RMarkdown format, which allows us to mix
text narrative, code, code-developed figures and items from the web in a
seamless document.

Then we can try to create something in the lines of what Hans Rosling
did.

Something that can:\
- provide a visualization\
- provide insight\
- tell a story\
- is reproducible

## References:

1.  <https://ysc-rmarkdown.netlify.app/slides/01-basics.html> Nice
    RMarkdown presentation and *"code movies"* !

2.  <https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/index.html>

3.  <https://www.markdowntutorial.com>

4.  https://andrewbtran.github.io/NICAR/2018/workflow/docs/02-rmarkdown.html

5.  https://yihui.name/tinytex/ *(install!)*

6.  https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/master/rmarkdown-2.0.pdf

7.  https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/html_document_format.html

8.  https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/pdf_document_format.html

## Assignment(s)

1.  Complete the markdowntutorial in \[reference 1\]

2.  Create a fresh RMarkdown document and use as many as possible of the
    RMarkdown constructs from the Cheatsheet \[reference 4\]

## Optional

3.  Go to reference 3 and install **tinytex**. Try to `knit` your
    document into PDF also, using `tinytex`.

## Fun Stuff
